Ohio craftsman James Mellick designed the exhibit to be symbolic of the wounds suffered by military dogs in battle and to raise awareness of their needs. The exhibit also features art depicting working military dogs from the Air Force Art Program. It will remain at the museum through Jan. 31.

Oklahoma

Oklahoma City: District attorneys are raising concerns about a proposed new ballot measure aimed at further reducing the state’s prison population. In a statement late Tuesday, Oklahoma District Attorneys Association President Jason Hicks says one problem is that crimes like child trafficking, aggravated assault and battery, and domestic abuse aren’t technically violent crimes under state law. The proposed state question filed Tuesday would prohibit prosecutors from using previous nonviolent felony convictions to enhance prison sentences. Hicks says state prosecutors are still examining the proposal, but there are already elements that would be “detrimental, if not catastrophic, for public safety.” District Attorney Angela Marsee says ignoring past convictions of repeat offenders is “detrimental to our mission.”

Oregon

Medford: Traditional Christmas feasts featuring Dungeness crab may not be in the cards this year, as officials have delayed the commercial crabbing season due to the small size of the crustaceans. The Mail Tribune reports the season had been set to start Dec. 1 for Oregon’s most lucrative commercial fishery, but now crabbing has been postponed until at least Dec. 16. It’s the sixth straight year the season has been delayed to allow the crabs a chance to fatten up to meet industry standards. Dungeness crabs off the coasts of Washington and California also have low meat levels in their shells, prompting similar delays in those states. Tests planned for late November or early December will determine whether commercial crabbers can start plying the Pacific beginning Dec. 16.

Pennsylvania

Harrisburg: The FBI has begun a corruption investigation into how Gov. Tom Wolf’s administration came to issue permits for construction on a multibillion-dollar pipeline project to carry highly volatile natural gas liquids across the state. FBI agents have interviewed current or former state employees in recent weeks about the Mariner East project and the construction permits, according to three people who have direct knowledge of the agents’ line of questioning. All three spoke on condition of anonymity. The focus of the agents’ questions involves the permitting of the pipeline, whether Wolf and his administration forced environmental protection staff to approve construction permits, and whether Wolf or his administration received anything in return, those people say.

Rhode Island

Providence: A federal judge has sided with the cities of Providence and Central Falls after they challenged the conditions of U.S. Department of Justice public safety grants they said in a lawsuit would turn local police into federal immigration agents. District Court Judge John McConnell Jr. said in a ruling Thursday that “Congress has not granted the power to impose the conditions the DOJ imposed.” The federal government, among other things, wanted cities receiving public safety grants to notify federal agents when immigrants in the country illegally are about to be released. Attorneys for the cities said in a statement that they are pleased the court “found DOJ’s attempts requiring our police departments to be agents of a federal immigration system to be unlawful.”

South Carolina

Clemson: Bars throughout downtown in this college town are now signed on to the Angel Shot program, offering patrons a way to request help when they don’t feel safe. The simple order – “one Angel Shot, please” – is meant to be a simple solution to combat sexual violence and assault in the university’s entertainment district. An “Angel Shot” is not an actual drink. It is a code word that signals to a bartender or barback that a customer feels unsafe, typically from a potential perpetrator of sexual violence. From there, the bar’s staff will find that customer safe passage out of the bar and home. The Angel Shot program was implemented in every bar downtown this fall semester by Clemson University Student Government, which partnered with Pickens County Advocacy Center, Clemson City Police Department and Clemson’s Healthy Campus for the initiative.

South Dakota

Sioux Falls: A man sentenced to 90 years in prison for killing his stepfather has petitioned the court in Minnehaha County to change his name because he wants a fresh start. Thirty-five-year-old Daniel Charles was 14 when he was sent to prison in 2000 for first-degree murder in Meade County. He was accused of putting a rifle to his stepfather’s head and pulling the trigger at a ranch near Opal. He told law enforcement at the time that he didn’t know the gun was loaded. Charles’ petition says he wants to change his name to Rameus Tiberius Aryada to start a new life with an adult identity. The South Dakota Department of Corrections lists Charles’ earliest parole eligibility as March 2045.

Tennessee

Nashville: The Tennessee State Museum is collecting stories of cultural identity, immigration and migration from the public. The project called Your Story, Our Story uses everyday objects as an entry point for these personal stories. Members of the public can add their own stories and read the stories of others on the Tennessee State Museum’s website. Because the museum is currently showcasing an exhibit on Tennessee food, it is especially encouraging visitors to add images and stories of recipes, cookware, dinnerware and ingredients that carry meaning in their families. Your Story, Our Story is an initiative of the Tenement Museum in New York City and partners across the U.S. that include museums, colleges, schools, libraries and community groups.

Texas

Robstown: With help from Nueces County Public Libraries, county Judge Barbara Canales led local students on a “bear hunt” at Oscar O. Ortiz Park on Wednesday evening. Despite the biting cold, Canales gamely led the students down a path to read from “We’re Going on a Bear Hunt” by Michael Rosen. The county unveiled StoryWalk, a new feature at the park in which pages of picture books are displayed in wooden stands along paths so residents can read while they walk. It’s an effort to promote literacy and physical activity, and the county plans to implement StoryWalk at more parks. Canales and the kids read aloud together as the characters braved tall grass, a deep river, a forest and mud along their search for a bear. Canales called out to the students to stomp in big strides, run and tip-toe like the characters to bring the story to life.

Utah

Salt Lake City: Former Gov. Jon Huntsman Jr. on Thursday announced his 2020 candidacy for the Republican nomination for the office that he held from 2005 to 2009 before leaving to serve as a U.S. ambassador. Huntsman announced his candidacy in a statement before a scheduled kickoff swing Thursday and Friday to Cedar City and St. George in southern Utah. Incumbent Republican Gov. Gary Herbert is not running for reelection, and Huntsman has said he was considering a run for governor. Huntsman served as U.S. ambassador to China in the Obama administration and as U.S. ambassador to Russia in the Trump administration. Other Republicans in the 2020 race include Lt. Gov. Spencer Cox, Utah County businessman Jeff Burningham and Salt Lake County Councilwoman Aimee Winder Newton.

Vermont

Montpelier: Five groups are sharing more than $1 million to use phosphorus recovery technologies as the state works to reduce algae-causing phosphorus runoff into Lake Champlain and other waterways. It’s part of the Vermont Phosphorus Innovation Challenge announced last year to generate creative solutions to the phosphorus pollution in the state. Officials estimate about 38% of the phosphorus load in the lake comes from agricultural land. Gov. Phil Scott said Thursday that the state received 21 applicants for the funds. The finalists include Agrilab Technologies of Enosburg Falls. The governor’s office says the group will use existing phosphorus recovery technologies, composting and drying equipment to create a series of sites for phosphorus processing in Franklin, Addison, Lamoille and Caledonia counties.

Virginia

Richmond: A task force has been created to come up with ways to help mitigate and prevent evictions in the city. The group will include affordable housing and social justice advocates, youth and family homelessness specialists, public housing residents and property management professionals. Mayor Levar Stoney said in a news release that the group will work with the city’s Eviction Diversion Program, which began last month to provide rental assistance, free legal help, financial counseling and supportive service referrals to residents who are facing eviction. Stoney said the task force will explore steps the city can take to better understand the root causes of evictions. A research group at Princeton University found that Richmond and four other Virginia cities have some of the highest eviction rates in the country.

Washington

Seattle: A weeklong hearing will help determine whether a small American Indian tribe from the northwest corner of Washington state can once again hunt whales. The Makah Tribe conducted its last legal hunt in 1999, when its crew harpooned a gray whale from a cedar canoe. A U.S. appeals court later revoked permission for the hunts, saying the tribe needed to obtain a waiver under the Marine Mammal Protection Act. The tribe has been trying to obtain the waiver since 2005, a process that has been repeatedly stalled by scientific reviews. The hearing beginning Thursday will focus on whether the tribe meets the requirements for the waiver. Animal rights groups oppose the effort. Whatever the outcome, the matter is likely to end up in federal court.

West Virginia

Charleston: The West Virginia Board of Education will give the public 60 days to comment on a proposal on charter schools, double the normal allotted time. The board put the policy proposal up for comment Thursday. Legislation signed by Gov. Jim Justice authorizes a staggered implementation of public charter schools, limiting the state to three charters until 2023, then three more every three years after that. The legislation was part of a broader education bill that included teacher pay raises. The West Virginia Education Association and the West Virginia chapter of the American Federation of Teachers have lambasted the bill, saying it shut out teachers’ voices and violates the state Constitution.

Wisconsin

Madison: Gov. Tony Evers is asking the Republican leaders of the Legislature’s budget committee to release $3.7 million a year in funding to pay for programs designed to help homeless people. Evers sent a letter Thursday to the committee cochairs, urging them to make available the funding that has been pending for four months. Evers is seeking action now before winter sets in. He says with cold temperatures and snow across the state already, “my concern has only grown.” The funding would go toward such things as grants to help low-income people with housing costs, help fund emergency shelters and pay for support to help homeless people get into permanent housing. The Assembly passed bills to approve the funding, but they’ve stalled in the Senate.

Wyoming

Yellowstone National Park: The National Park Service says snowy weather last month likely cut down on visitors to Yellowstone during October. The agency recorded just over 170,000 visitors during the month, a 22% decrease from October 2018. So far in 2019, the park has hosted over 3.9 million visitors, which is down 2.5% from the same period last year. Yellowstone is entering its winter season, when visits to the park are typically the lowest of the year.

From USA TODAY Network and wire reports

search_result.title: Missing Iowans remembered, families supported at Waterloo vigil
search_result.text:
WATERLOO, Ia. — Elizabeth Collins would have turned 15 this week.

To celebrate, her family and friends sang a birthday song, ate cake and released lanterns and balloons Tuesday at Angels Park, a community healing project where the abandoned bikes of her and her cousin were found in July 2012. Months after finding the bikes, the bodies of the kidnapped girls were discovered in a wildlife area.

Now, more than six years later, Elizabeth's mother, Heather, feels sick when she sees reports of missing children and young adults. She understands the anxiety their family and friends are experiencing.

"It's like a club, an unwanted club," she said in a shirt displaying the faces of Elizabeth and her cousin, Lyric Cook-Morrissey. "It's still a nightmare every day that I wake up."

Standing at a podium during a vigil Wednesday, with family members of missing people seated behind her, Heather Collins had a message: "We will bring these kids home."

More than 200 people gathered at the RiverLoop Amphitheatre & Expo Plaza in Waterloo to show support for the families of Mollie Tibbetts, a University of Iowa student who vanished two weeks ago, and Jake Wilson, an autistic teenager who disappeared in April from La Porte City.

Tibbetts' cousin Morgan Collum, 27, called the turnout amazing and thanked the crowd for supporting her family. She described the last two weeks as difficult, saying when she looks in the mirror each morning, she thinks to herself, "How am I going to get through this day?"

Amanda Goodman, a former KWWL anchor who works as the executive director of Family & Children's Council of Black Hawk County, said for more than 100 days, Jake's family has wondered if he is hurt, hungry or scared.

Goodman said Jake's family needs him home. She pointed at his mother, Megan Neiswonger, and told the crowd: "That is his mother right there; he is not a statistic."

And then two weeks ago when Tibbetts vanished, "it was like a punch in the gut," Goodman said. She described the region as shook by the disappearances.

"Today, we are the shocked neighbor," Waterloo Mayor Quentin Hart said.

Family members of 14-year-old Kaiden Douglas Estling, of Maynard, also sat in front of the amphitheater. Estling was killed last month when he was struck on a moped by another vehicle; no one has been arrested in connection with the hit-and-run death.

The vigil was attended by police chiefs from the area and two state representatives.

Waterloo Police Chief Dan Trelka called on Iowans to be vigilant of their surroundings and to better know their neighbors, telling the crowd: "There is evil is lurking among us." He promised those missing they would not be forgotten.

Trelka also had a message to predators of children: "We will hunt you down to the ends of the earth."

Previous coverage on the search for Mollie Tibbetts:

Despite concern among some citizens, agents with the Iowa Division of Criminal Investigation have said there was no evidence to suggest the missing person cases were connected.

State investigators have also said the number of missing juveniles reported in Iowa in recent weeks was in line with historical trends. The vast majority are found or returned home within 24 hours.

At the vigil, state Rep. Jeff Danielson, a Democrat from Waterloo, suggested upgrading the state’s Amber Alert system, which he called important but limited. While Iowans prides themselves on raising children, “we have to do better,” he said.

Tibbetts, 20, disappeared after running on the night of July 18 while dog-sitting at the home of her boyfriend and his brother on the western edge of Brooklyn, a city of about 1,500 residents in east-central Iowa. Her disappearance has gained national attention.

During a news conference Tuesday, state officials said investigators were continuing to follow up on all new leads they received but declined to comment on specific details. When asked whether it was likely Tibbetts had been abducted, one responded that authorities "don't know where Mollie's at right now."

Previous coverage on the search for Mollie Tibbetts:

Poweshiek County Sheriff Thomas Kriegel said more than 200 leads had been followed up on that included ground, air and K-9 unit searches. As many as 40 investigators have worked on the case each day, he said.

"Everybody wants to find Mollie and, at this point, we're doing everything we can to make that happen," Kevin Winker, director of investigative operations at the Iowa Department of Public Safety, told reporters. "Our focus right now is to find Mollie."

There have been few updates on the search for Jake. In an interview before Wednesday's vigil, La Porte City Police Chief Chris Brecher said authorities have received a number of reported sightings of the teenager in other states, none of which turned out to be him.

Those tips have been coming in from states farther than usual since the A&E Network television series "Live PD" featured Jake's disappearance in June. The show has since highlighted information about Mollie's case.

Previous coverage on the search for Jake Wilson:

Jake, 5-foot-6 and 135 pounds, was last seen April 7 going for a walk to Wolf Creek, which runs through La Porte City. The outgoing nature-lover left without his glasses and was wearing a brown zip-up hooded sweatshirt, dark pants and cowboy boots.

Police in the community of about 2,200 people used an array of techniques and machinery to clear the creek, which officials had described as their "main culprit."

More:Iowa's list of missing people has 300+ names. Here's what we know about them.

They sent dive teams in the creek; used a helicopter from the Iowa National Guard, hovering above in the hopes of moving objects under the water; they called on the public to raise money for an excavator to pull logs and large trees out of the water.

The teenager's parents "still have an optimism that Jake is out there," Brecher said. After the vigil, his mother walked with Goodman to a railing near the Cedar River, releasing a white balloon into the sky.

Years later, no one has been arrested in the killings of 8-year-old Elizabeth Collins and 10-year-old Lyric Cook.

More:Pain of 2 Iowa girls' killings remains, but resolve in Evansdale only grows

When the girls disappeared, thousands of volunteers searched for them as people across the country called in tips, claiming to have spotted them. Their bodies were found about 20 miles northeast of Evansdale, a 5,000-person town outside Waterloo, in a remote area of the Seven Bridges Wildlife Area.

Heather Collins brought a map to the vigil that pinpointed where people had been reported missing since mid-July throughout the state. Most were teenagers, and while some were runaways, they were still missed by their families, she said.

Drew Collins, Elizabeth’s father, gave $9,000 raised during an annual bike ride to honor the cousins to the Cedar Valley Crime Stoppers and another $9,000 to Angels Park.

“I don’t want to see this happen to anyone else,” Collins said, adding he believed whoever killed his daughter and niece would “have to answer to God.”

“Amazing Grace” played as those gathered lit candles, some people teared up. Talking about Tibbetts and Jake, Goodman told the group they were “lighting their way home.”

How to contact law enforcement

Authorities are asking anyone with information about Mollie Tibbetts to contact the Poweshiek County Sheriff’s Office at 641-623-5679 or tips@poweshiekcosheriff.com.

Police are asking anyone with information about Jake Wilson to call 319-342-2232. The FBI created a website, www.fbi.gov/laportecityiowa, where people can upload photos or videos taken in La Porte City on the day he went missing.

Anyone with information about the hit-and-run death of Kaiden Douglas Estling has been asked to call the Fayette County Sheriff's Office at 563-422-3234.

Evansdale police have asked anyone with information about the killing of the cousins Elizabeth Collins and Lyric Cook call them at 319-232-6682.

Follow the Des Moines Register on Facebook and Twitter for updates.

search_result.title: How Detroit Mayor Mike Duggan's past, history have guided him in ...
search_result.text:
Hundreds of Detroit police were in quarantine and, despite his public comments, Mayor Mike Duggan was worried the city might not have enough cops to work the streets.

So he did what he does best: He worked the phones.

Reaching out to a friend who was a partner in the Chicago office of Skadden Arps, a multinational law firm, Duggan asked if they could put him in touch with Abbott, a medical devices company in the Chicago suburbs.

It was March 27, a Friday, and Duggan had just read that Abbott received emergency use authorization for a novel coronavirus testing machine that provides results in about 15 minutes.

Twenty-four hours later, at about 10 o’clock on Saturday night, Duggan got a text saying the CEO of Abbott would talk to him.

“I think I did wake him up,” Duggan said months later of his call to outgoing CEO Miles White. “What I said to him was ‘I got 600 cops on quarantine, four-day turnaround on tests isn’t working, I need instant results.”

With the pandemic raging and ravaging big cities — New York City was averaging 500 cases a day at the time — Abbott had more demand than machines.

Nevertheless, at 11:30 a.m. Sunday, March 29, incoming Abbott CEO Robert Ford agreed to send machines to Detroit.

“Mayor Duggan expressed what you would want to hear from every mayor and governor around the country during a health crisis —– a deep commitment to ensuring his city had all the necessary resources to battle this pandemic,” Ford said in a statement sent to the Free Press. “He was especially focused on making sure the city’s health care workers, firefighters and police force could get tested and back to work.”

Duggan said the deal for five machines was done by 2 p.m.

By April 1, a Wednesday, the machines were here, making Detroit the first city performing rapid tests to help get first responders and bus drivers back to work. The number of city employees in quarantine plummeted.

“That was really the turning point for everything,” Duggan said during an interview with the Free Press in late May, during a brief lull in a summer and fall packed with a pandemic, protests, politics and even a plot to kidnap the governor.

The call to Abbott labs was not the first time, and would not be the last time, Duggan worked the network of contacts he built up over 25 years in public office and nearly a decade as CEO of a major hospital system to help Detroit cope with the pandemic that has killed 1,622 Detroiters and infected another 20,883, as of Wednesday.

The crisis has shuttered businesses and schools and changed our lives in ways even experts had not predicted when Duggan held his first coronavirus briefing on March 11. It also shifted attention from some challenges Duggan was facing at the time, including criticism from within city hall for his demolition program and efforts to aid a nonprofit run by a friend, to community activists demanding that the mayor find $600 million to compensate residents whose properties had been overtaxed before Duggan took office.

Critics include Anthony Adams, a lawyer who has worked for Mayor Coleman Young and Mayor Kwame Kilpatrick. He said the pandemic has allowed Duggan to shift the focus.

“Pre-COVID, there appeared to be a tremendous movement in opposition to the policies that were being proposed,” Adams said, accusing Duggan of catering to the city’s business class at the expense of its working class.

Adams, who is expected to run against Duggan next year, said Detroiters were mobilizing in opposition to the city policy of shutting off water for customers who did not pay their bills as well as Duggan’s determination that the city could not afford to reimburse overtaxed residents.

“That organic movement was gaining strength, and COVID became a breakpoint because, obviously, public meetings and public discussion was severely limited,” Adams said. “It’s a perfect recipe for government secrecy, because people can’t examine all your decisions. All you can see is a talking head citing facts and figures and appearing to do the right thing … Average Detroiters are still suffering.”

Alexis Wiley, the former Duggan chief of staff who left the administration to work on the mayor’s bid for a third term, said the mayor was made for this moment.

“With his background in health care and running a hospital that was about to go into bankruptcy, this is his sweet spot,” she said. “It’s a blend of politics, finances and science — and there’s no blue print.”

“At his core, this is what he’s for,” Wiley added. “He’s a war-time general.”

What isn’t debatable is that Duggan has come a long way from his days coaching fifth grade girls in Livonia.

Type A — and then some

Duggan, 62, was in grade school when he worked on his first campaign in 1965.

Patrick Duggan Jr. — his dad — lost that bid for district court judge.

“I was in second grade then, so I don't take responsibility for that one,” Duggan said years later, long after his father had become a federal judge.

By the time he was 11, Duggan was singing campaign songs at shopping centers with the Mini-Macs, a group of kids his mother organized to support Ed McNamara’s run for mayor of Livonia.

“The shopping center manager would try to throw them out, and Mike would start debating whether he could or not,” McNamara told Corporate Detroit magazine more than 20 years later.

Even as coach of the Roadrunners, Duggan was a master strategist.

Greg Budde, Duggan’s friend since 1972, said he helped Duggan coach the girls’ baseball and softball team in Livonia. The future mayor told the Roadrunners he was going to be general manager of the Detroit Tigers someday. In the meantime, he focused on teaching the girls how to slide, how to run down a deep fly ball — and more.

If there was a pop-up, Duggan would say: “‘Catch the ball, Ellen!’” Budde recalled. “And we didn’t have a girl named Ellen.”

"Ellen" was code for a player to drop the ball to set up a double-play.

Sports and politics were a big part of Duggan’s upbringing in the Livonia home where he lived with his four brothers and civic-minded parents. So was debate, which was as big a deal as sports at uber-competitive Detroit Catholic Central High School.

By 1976, Duggan and Dan Mulhern were among the top high school debaters in the country.

Mulhern, who attended University of Detroit Jesuit High School, said he and his partner won just about every tournament they entered that fall, besting Duggan on multiple occasions.

Mulhern said he was "rubbing the sleep out of my eyes and looking around for old friends and cute girls” before a meet early one Saturday morning when Duggan picked him out of the crowd.

With an “ear-to-ear, confident grin,” Duggan declared: “Mulhern, if we face you today, I’m gonna kick your ass.”

Brash and confident, Duggan aimed to rattle opponents. He and his partner worked hard and were aggressive, even interrupting opponents.

“That was unusual,” Mulhern said. “They were very edgy — Mike was very edgy in that way.”

Mulhern and Duggan met again months later, during a competition hosted by the University of Pittsburgh.

There were about 100 teams competing. Duggan only cared about one.

“Mike had prepared an entire round of speeches exclusively for us,” Mulhern recalled. “They had watched the game film, so to speak, and mapped our every move. And they destroyed us.”

“In a world of competitors,” Mulhern said, “Mike was the fiercest in the jungle.”

Adventures in Wayne County

In 1982, Duggan was a soldier in McNamara’s campaign for Wayne County executive.

McNamara lost.

In 1986, Duggan was the general.

McNamara won.

So he made the 28-year-old lawyer his top deputy.

One of Duggan’s early prized recruits was a recent law school grad: Mulhern.

“On my first day of work, he introduced me to Bob Wisler, one of Ed McNamara's longest-serving aides, who, like McNamara, was literally more than twice our age,” Mulhern recalled.

He said Duggan told Wisler: “‘This is Dan Mulhern, and you're in his office. When are you going to be out of here?’”

“I'm not sure who felt more embarrassed, me or Wisler,” Mulhern said. “He just kind of smirked and shook his head and, in today’s language, said, ‘Whatever, Mike.’

“But he knew he had to go.”

Duggan said recently that Mulhern might not have known that Wisler was being moved to a bigger office as part of a reorganization. He said Wisler is a long-time family friend and knew he was only kidding.

McNamara’s administration eliminated a $135 million deficit it inherited, improved the county’s bond rating, helped negotiate deals for Comerica Park and Ford Field, launched environmental initiatives and improved or replaced county facilities ranging from the morgue to the juvenile jail to Metro Airport, which added runways and new terminals as part of a $1.6 billion overhaul.

It was also plagued by questions about contracting and cronyism before a federal public corruption investigation made headlines. In the end, the only people convicted were three little-known political appointees.

Duggan said he had been recruited to work in the county's legal department by John O'Hair, who was doing double duty as corporation counsel and prosecutor when McNamara made Duggan his second-in-command. As one of the most powerful officials in Wayne County, Duggan was seldom far from the action, which ranged from being tasked with saving public transportation to being accused of meddling in the investigation of Malice Green, a Black man who died after a Detroit police officer beat him during a traffic stop in 1992.

Then, as now, Duggan was data-driven, with giant flow charts adorning the walls of his office.

“He’s always been a guy who looks at the numbers to see the trends, and for accountability as well,” said June West, who Duggan hired as marketing director for SMART, the failing suburban bus system.

West said SMART was three weeks away from being unable to meet payroll when Duggan retooled the system and rallied public support. She said he replaced quarterly directors meetings with weekly meetings, and talked with bus drivers, mechanics and dispatchers to “find out from them how things could be done better.”

“He would work all day, he would leave at whatever time to get home for the kids’ soccer practice … and then he’d come back to work,” West said. “He knows how to fix things — and there are always things that need to be fixed,” she said. “Complacency is not part of his DNA. It’s always about how we can do this better.”

In 1992, Duggan was essentially working two full-time jobs — deputy county executive by day, general manager of SMART by night — when Green died. Young, Detroit's mayor, said Green was “literally murdered by police.”

Three years later, Kalil Jiraki, a former county pathologist, sued the county, his boss, Duggan and another county official. He said his boss and Duggan tried to make him change his autopsy findings to say that cocaine contributed to Green's death and that, after he refused, they tried to destroy his reputation and fired him.

Jiraki’s attorney Mike Stefani told jurors that the medical examiner and Duggan pressured Jiraki to blame Green's death on cocaine to pacify predominantly white suburbanite voters, who felt that the white cops were getting a raw deal.

During a deposition, Duggan denied interfering, calling O’Hair: “the closest thing to a mentor I have ever had.

“He is a close friend of my boss,” Duggan added. “The idea that we would at any point try to undercut his prosecution is absurd.”

He said that if any Wayne County employees had tried to undermine the case against the officers, “I would have fired them myself.”

Duggan said he always supported prosecuting the officers and accused the cops’ supporters of putting out racist literature.

“I find them offensive,” Duggan said. “I think it's a disgusting group.”

A judge dismissed Duggan from the lawsuit, which Jiraki won in 1997. A jury awarded him $2.5 million.

A year later, Duggan helped Mulhern’s wife Jennifer Granholm, who also worked for the county, win the Democratic nomination for attorney general. She became the first woman elected to that post. Four years later, Mulhern became Michigan’s first First Gentleman when voters made Granholm the first woman elected governor.

In between those campaigns, Duggan put his own name on the ballot, running in 2000 for Wayne County prosecutor.

Redefining the role

In 2001, Duggan’s first year on the job, prosecutors seized 146 houses in a crackdown on drug dens and derelict landlords.

In 2000, O’Hair’s last year as the county’s top law enforcement official, the prosecutor’s office seized one house.

Those figures, reported by the Detroit News, captured the new focus and aggressiveness Duggan brought to the job.

Even though he had never handled a criminal case or worked in the prosecutor’s office, Duggan vowed to get more production out of the staff, as well as crack down on gun crime, deadbeats and scofflaws. The Free Press and News had recently published major investigations into the number of people shot by Detroit police. So Duggan announced he would create a new unit to review police shootings.

He said the reviews would be “very aggressive.”

Trigger-happy cops weren’t the only ones in Duggan’s cross-hairs.

He needed money to give prosecutors raises, so he increased the fee for Johns to get their cars back after they were stopped for soliciting prostitutes. The cost jumped from $250 to $900, bringing in hundreds of thousands of dollars. Duggan said his annual goal was $2 million.

In March 2003, the prosecutor’s office launched “Johns TV," a 15-minute show broadcasting the names and faces of men convicted of soliciting prostitutes. It included warnings about sexually transmitted diseases and encouraged practitioners of the oldest profession to find a new line of work.

Duggan’s crackdown on quality of life crimes included taking a hard line on graffiti. In one case, he pushed for two-month jail sentences for nationally known graffiti artists convicted of misdemeanors for tagging a vacant building without permission.

And then, just as his political career was taking off, it was over.

Profit — and problems

For years, the flow of red ink at the Detroit Medical Center resembled the arterial spray from a machete attack.

The DMC was one of Detroit’s largest employers, operated one of the region’s best and busiest emergency rooms, and served as a training ground for Wayne State University medical students as well as a crucial source of care for the needy.

Granholm tried to stanch the bleeding with a $50 million state bailout before the hospital turned to Duggan in desperation.

Duggan recently said the money was spent by the time he got the job. Still, the DMC made a small profit in 2004, Duggan’s first year on the job.

Before long, the political operator who had once eschewed the spotlight became the voice of the DMC, promising in a blitz of radio advertisements to cut wait time at the system’s hospitals to 30 minutes or less. Hospitals throughout the region rushed to match the DMC’s promise.

Instead of closing hospitals, DMC branched out. It made money every year of Duggan’s tenure, raking in $44.7 million in 2009.

In 2010, for-profit Tennessee-based Vanguard Health Systems initiated the purchase of the non-profit DMC. Critics worried the sale would undercut the DMC’s community-oriented mission. Duggan said an infusion of cash from a new owner was the only way the system could afford upgrades it needed to compete with rivals building swanky new facilities in the suburbs.

But before the deal could be completed, DMC officials contacted federal prosecutors to disclose potentially improper financial relationships with more than 250 physicians.

Crain’s Detroit Business reported that the deals occurred between 2004 and 2010 — Duggan’s tenure as CEO — and included “below-market leases with doctors, free advertising, marketing and tickets to sporting events and educational seminars.”

“Many of the violations appear to be related to efforts by Duggan to bring more physician referrals to the DMC,” Crain’s reported, adding that there were also problems with documentation for Medicare and Medicaid billings for physician services from 2007 to 2010.

DMC announced on Dec. 30, 2010 that it would pay the federal government a $30 million settlement. Duggan described the problems as minor “technical violations” and the DMC did not admit wrongdoing.

Peter Caplan, a federal prosecutor assigned to the case, told Crain’s “the $30 million was not a slap on the wrist in any circumstances.”

“It is a substantial amount of money, and it was as much as the government could get from DMC without preventing the deal from closing,” he said, adding: “We also did not want to see the hospital (system) close.”

The $1.5 billion sale of the Detroit institution to Nashville-based Vanguard closed the next day.

Duggan stayed on, but soon began exploring other options.

In February 2012, he bought a house in Detroit’s leafy Palmer Woods neighborhood.

In the fall, Duggan told DMC employees he was cutting his salary and workload as he considered running for mayor of Detroit.

In, out, write-in

It’s said that Duggan likes nothing more than a problem.

“He sees a problem and he wants to fix it,” said Craig Fahle, who interviewed Duggan while working at Detroit Public Radio and, later, worked with him after joining the Detroit Land Bank. “For people who like a challenge, you can’t find one much bigger than the city of Detroit.”

But Duggan couldn't conceive of a solution to the problem he encountered when a judge threw him off the 2013 primary ballot for filing his campaign paper work less than a year after he registered to vote in Detroit.

After the Michigan Court of Appeals upheld the ruling, Duggan said he wouldn’t appeal to the Michigan Supreme Court.

Almost before it began, his mayoral campaign was over.

But not for long.

Supporters began talking about a write-in campaign. Soon, Detroit’s corporate leaders began writing big checks to a committee touting Duggan for mayor. Turnaround Detroit raised $1.4 million and launched a pro-Duggan media blitz. That effort, coupled with Duggan’s superior organization and the more than $1 million his campaign raised, helped him finish first in the primary. Duggan beat Wayne County Sheriff Benny Napoleon by 10% in the general election.

Detroit’s new mayor again targeted improving emergency response time and eliminating blight.

Portia Roberson, whom Duggan had recruited to work for him in the prosecutor’s office and, later, at DMC, said the mayor is driven and wants to surround himself with people who are smart and hard workers.

So he started recruiting, asking businesses to connect him with people who knew how to implement Lean and Six Sigma, which are business programs designed to improve efficiency, reduce waste and maximize customer satisfaction.

Bethany Melitz, who started as a member of the Lean team and rose to chief administrative officer before leaving in April, said Duggan meets with as many people as possible.

“He just wanted to hear … what systems would fix their problems,” she said.

Because public safety is one of his priorities, Duggan has met with gang members in a city park.

Melitz recalled the mayor telling a gang member at one meeting: “I’m trying to reduce crime in the city. I’m trying to understand why it’s happening. What do you guys need from the city in order to be productive members?”

“One of the people said: ‘There’s a house next to me that needs to be demoed,’ ” Melitz said, adding that a couple others said they needed jobs.

She believes the house got knocked down. And she said the other guys got jobs in the city’s General Services Department.

“He doesn’t assume he knows why people do things,” Melitz said of the mayor. “He always wants to hear it from them … If he wants to know why do people shoot things, then he’s got to talk to the shooters.”

Conversations with Duggan’s subordinates from his county days to the present yield similar evaluations: He is often the smartest guy in the room, he loves data, he solicits input but doesn’t tolerate fools, he asks lots of questions, he works hard, he is resourceful, he demands results, and he trusts but verifies.

Brad Dick, Duggan’s Group Executive for Infrastructure, started with the city in 2006. He said he met Duggan when the mayor dropped by a city garage.

“Out of the corner of my eye I saw a guy standing there and I said, ‘What’s that guy doing?’” Dick recalled. “And I said, ‘Can I help you, sir?’ ”

The man started asking questions.

“And then I said, ‘Ohmigod, you’re the mayor!’”

Another time, he said, Duggan was emphasizing trash pickup. So the mayor drove around until he found a street with trash cans still on the curb.

Dick said Duggan was looking into one of them when a neighbor called out: “Hey, get out of my trash can!”

“There’s no hiding anything from him,” Dick said. “He gets to the bottom of everything. He gets to the root cause.”

Fahle said Duggan is demanding, but not unreasonable.

“He always wanted us to be as prepared to answer as many questions as we could,” he said. “And if we didn’t know, he wanted us to get answers the next day.”

Roberson, who worked for Mayor Dave Bing for about 18 months before Duggan succeeded him, said Duggan has high expectations.

“He will say: ‘Nope, you’ve got to get this done. And you’ve got to get this done now.' ”

Roberson and Fahle said Duggan motivates by challenging people to keep up with him. And, if they can’t, that’s too bad — for them.

“He’s not going to be your best chum or anything like that,” Fahle said.

“I don’t think Mike worries too much about what people will say about him,” Roberson said.

But there are also stories about Duggan taking a personal interest in employees’ medical needs — even making calls and recommending doctors.

“When my dad passed away, he sent me the nicest, kindest text message I’ve ever seen,” Dick said.

Melitz said Duggan allowed her to bring her toddler to cabinet meetings, the weekly sessions where Duggan quizzes his staff and gives marching orders.

Mulhern, who debated Duggan in high school and later worked for him at Wayne County, called the mayor a “pacesetter.”

“You know that you were working harder than anybody, but you had to keep up,” Mulhern said. “But don’t expect praise after the first two weeks.”

“It was about the work. It wasn’t about people feeling good.”

In an interview with the Free Press earlier this year, Duggan said: “I never have to fire anybody. The people who are committed to making this city better oftentimes find they accomplish far more than they thought they could when they’re part of a team like this.”

“We have a saying: ‘I really don’t care about the quality of your excuses.’ ”

Missteps and controversies

Despite his love of data and legendary attention to detail, Duggan's insatiable drive for results has a tendency to get him in trouble.

In his first term, Duggan’s team got caught fudging numbers on the cost of demolition and had to return millions of dollars in state grants. The state ended up sending the money back to knock down more buildings.

Duggan took the blame for the problems, telling reporters he may have pushed his team so hard that they were more focused on results than rules.

The demolition program has also been criticized for creating potential environmental hazards for neighbors exposed to the toxins released when a building is razed.

In October 2019, Detroit Inspector General Ellen Ha concluded that Make Your Date, the nonprofit created to reduce infant mortality run by Duggan’s friend, received preferential treatment because the mayor chose to partner with the program without first going through a competitive selection process.

Based on the evidence gathered, the OIG concludes that the selection of MYD lacked fairness, openness and transparency,” Ha wrote.

In November 2019, Detroit Auditor General Mark Lockridge blasted the city for having “inconsistent and unreliable” demolition data, as well as poor record keeping that made it difficult to perform the audit.

“A perception that public officials are using the procurement system to reward themselves, their friends, or supporters, poisons the public’s confidence in government and shakes its faith in the bureaucratic process,” Lockridge wrote.

Current and former employees said two causes of Duggan’s problems may be that government doesn’t move at the speed of Duggan — and Duggan’s faith in his own judgment.

“Mike belongs to a category of leader that are so focused on achieving results that they are going too quickly and they may make some mistakes, but they have supreme confidence that they can adjust,” Mulhern said. “I think Mike’s confidence gives him the ability to do things and adjust.”

Bob Ficano, former Wayne County executive, called Duggan a "very good administrator," but said "he pushes really hard and really quick and that's where it leads to those issues like the blighted houses.

"The train got ahead of itself."

A federal investigation into Detroit’s demolition program yielded convictions of a low-level Detroit Building Authority official and an employee of a demolition contractor. Federal prosecutors said they did not plan to charge any more Detroit officials.

A Nov. 29, 2018 FBI report the Free Press obtained that was written by the Detroit office’s top public corruption agent says: “Writer advised source, consistently with the advice writer has given the source in the past, that the FBI does not have a pending investigation of Mike Duggan.”

That source is Robert Carmack, a Detroit businessman who had been little-known outside political circles before 2018, when his property disputes with the city made headlines.

While Carmack and the city exchanged lawsuits in state and federal court, Carmack hired private investigators to follow Duggan. That effort yielded video of the mayor driving to a suburban home where he met on several evenings with a woman who was not his wife. Duggan said Carmack was trying to pressure him and declined to comment on the nature of his relationship with the woman, a doctor who ran Make Your Date. Six months later, the Duggans filed for divorce. They released a statement calling it a “painful decision” and vowing: “We will continue to be supportive of each other, of our family and of the citizens of Detroit.”

An April 25, 2018 FBI report the Free Press obtained revealed that city officials met with a federal prosecutor and FBI agent in early 2018 to discuss their investigation into one of Carmack’s land deals, which the city deemed fraudulent.

By December, city officials succeeded in convincing local prosecutors to charge Carmack with four felonies, including fraud, for collecting $1 million for the sale of land the city said it owned. Carmack argued that the city gave him the land in return for his investment in an earlier project that fell apart after he refused to give $50,000 to one of Mayor Kwame Kilpatrick’s henchmen.

Defense attorney Mike Rataj, who has consulted with Carmack, said the prosecution was designed to punish Carmack for exposing corruption.

“It’s clear that the city of Detroit does not have standing as an alleged victim in the case,” he said. “They don’t own the property that they claim Carmack stole from them.”

The first judge to review the evidence said she thought the case was thin, but sent it to trial. Jury selection is expected to start next year. Duggan has said the city is merely trying to defend its rights.

Mulhern, who is not familiar with the Carmack dispute, said Duggan is not vindictive, but takes actions that he thinks will yield long-term benefits.

“He would intimidate you or cut you off or run a candidate against you in order to do something in the future,” he said of Duggan’s days in Wayne County government. “It was a future focus, it wasn’t score settling.”

Ficano isn't so sure.

While serving as sheriff, Ficano battled with the McNamara administration over control of the Wayne County Jail.

"You definitely want to be his friend, not his enemy," Ficano said of Duggan. "He comes after you with both barrels."

Ficano, who had faced little competition in previous elections, said McNamara and Duggan recruited a candidate to run against him in 1992. He said his opponent raised about $1 million and nearly knocked him off.

"If he wants to go after something and you're on his radar screen, life isn't going to be very pleasant for you," Ficano said, adding that a truce was quickly negotiated after he survived the challenge.

In the days after Carmack held a news conference on Nov. 28, 2018 and suggested he had more incriminating video of Duggan, the mayor and Carmack tried privately through an intermediary to negotiate a truce. Duggan later said he was really just trying to collect more evidence against Carmack. A Dec. 17, 2018 FBI report the Free Press obtained said Carmack “does not have additional compromising video of the Mayor of Detroit” and

Carmack was “stringing (Duggan) along” in a bid to help him in one of his lawsuits against the city.

Amidst these public and private distractions, Duggan suffered a rare public setback.

The generally pliant city council rejected his request to put a $250 million demolition bond on the ballot. The mayor warned that the federal funds the city used to help tear down 17,000 abandoned buildings were nearly gone and, without $250 million, the city could not remove or renovate the city’s remaining blighted houses.

Behind the scenes, Duggan and his team worked with Fiat Chrysler on a plan to assemble land FCA needed to convert an idled engine plant into an assembly plant for a new three-row Jeep.

The FCA project promised thousands of jobs. It would be the first new auto plant to open in Detroit in more than a quarter century.

Then, on Jan. 9, 2020, the consummate problem solver inherited a new challenge. The Detroit News reported that the city overtaxed homeowners by failing to lower property values in the wake of the Great Recession, when home prices cratered and foreclosures flourished. The newspaper calculated that Detroit owed homeowners $600 million, and had created a tax burden that cost some people their homes.

Much of the overtaxation occurred before Duggan took office. In his first month on the job, he announced that he would lower property taxes by 5 to 20%. And even though Duggan ordered a reappraisal of every residential property in 2017 to correct the problem, activists demanded that the mayor offer refunds — and even homes — to people who lost their property to foreclosure.

In February, community activist Nicole Small led a meeting at a downtown union hall calling for action. Flyers handed out had the headlines “Make Us Whole” and “Cut The Damn Check, Mike!” over a photo of a downcast Duggan. On Feb. 28, protesters marched outside city hall and packed a city council meeting.

While Duggan acknowledged the over-assessment, he has said the city can't afford to pay back the $600 million and that the deadline to do so has passed. He added that most of those taxes were paid to the school district and other governmental agencies.

Small said she doesn’t buy it.

“He finds money for everything else,” she said.

As the property tax refund movement was gaining momentum, a little-known bug was also picking up speed, bearing down on Detroit.

A novel challenge

Detroit Chief Public Health Officer Denise Fair was at a Super Bowl party on Feb. 2, 2020 when she got word to prepare for a flight being diverted to Detroit.

Its point of origin?

Wuhan, China.

Fair started working for Detroit in September 2019. She said the coronavirus first came up in December. Planning for the pandemic began in early January.

But the gravity didn’t sink in until after the Super Bowl, when Fair participated in a conference call with local health officials, Michigan Chief Medical Executive Dr. Joneigh S. Khaldun, and federal officials.

“That’s when I knew this is really an all-hands-on-deck moment,” Fair said.

She said Detroit’s first coronavirus case came on March 11 — the same day Duggan held his first news briefing.

“There’s no reason to panic,” the mayor told reporters. “But there’s every reason to be prepared.”

The city announced several measures to fight the spread of the virus that causes COVID-19, including a new initiative to help Detroiters restore water service.

Adams, who ran the city’s water department under former Mayor Kwame Kilpatrick, later said the city’s decision to shut off water left poor Detroiters vulnerable to infection.

Duggan also recommended that people who have a fever, cough or shortness of breath — which initially were the leading signs of infection — stay indoors.

“If people who had these symptoms stayed home,” he said, “this outbreak would be brief.”

“This virus will stop spreading when we start being responsible to our neighbors,” Duggan said, adding that city officials were contemplating whether to cancel large public gatherings. The mayor had already urged organizers of the St. Patrick Parade to cancel the 62nd edition of the bacchanal to prevent tens of thousands of revelers from crowding the curbs along Michigan Avenue and packing the bars of Corktown.

On March 12, Duggan said he supported keeping schools open, did not plan to close recreation centers and was “looking at” whether casinos might pose a risk. After the Utah Jazz announced that two of their players were infected, the mayor declined to name the hotel where they stayed for their March 7 game with the Pistons. He said health officials inspected the hotel and were satisfied it had been sanitized.

“I thought his response was very, very secretive,” Adams said months later. “I found that unusual, because as a former health care executive … you begin contact tracing.”

“I didn’t really feel the empathy there from the mayor,” Adams added. “He kind of played it off as not being a really big deal.”

By March 13, Duggan’s briefing had taken a dire tone. He announced the closure of recreation centers and assigned their workers to help school officials deliver food to needy families.

“It’s clear we’ve moved to a different stage,” he said. “We need to be completely honest about what we’re facing. … This is not going to be over in a few weeks.”

Duggan said he expected the number of coronavirus cases to “grow dramatically.”

“We’re going to have to find a different way to live,” he said.

Months later, Duggan told the Free Press he underestimated the coronavirus threat.

“It was something that I’ve already lived through once,” he said, referring to the H1N1 swine flu pandemic that hit in 2009 while he was running the DMC. “It turned out to be something dramatically less than what was predicted, so the early predictions nationally that this wouldn’t be that big in America, I was kind of seeing it through my experience with H1N1 and I wasn’t focused on it being anywhere near what it was.”

Nevertheless, since mid-March, the rest of America has been trying to keep up with Detroit.

While Michigan — and the rest of the country — struggled to find test kits, Duggan convened local officials and hospital executives to collaborate on plans for a drive-through testing site.

“It was just so stark and so real; it was scary,” said Dick, who was charged with creating the test site at the state fairgrounds. “I looked at Alexis (Wiley) and I said, ‘I feel like we’re in a movie set where things end badly.’ ”

A key to the plan’s success — securing test kits — hinged on a call to JP Morgan Chase, the largest bank in America.

Duggan heard that BioReference, a New Jersey company, had ramped up its testing capacity. So the mayor reached out to JP Morgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon, who has praised Detroit and launched a $100 million investment program here in 2014.

“When the mayor calls and has an urgent need, we try to be helpful,” said Peter Scher, the bank’s head of corporate responsibility.

He said the bank had heard of BioReference, but didn’t know the company well. Still, they reached out to CEO Phil Frost and told him Detroit was important to JP Morgan “and we had huge confidence in the mayor.”

Scher said BioReference was only doing testing for New York and New Jersey, but agreed to speak to Duggan.

A couple hours later, on March 18, a Wednesday, BioReference and Duggan connected. The mayor's father died that day. Duggan said he stepped out of his mom's condo to take the call from BioReference executive chairman Jon Cohen.

“And, by Friday, they had the deal for testing,” Scher said.

Duggan said BioReference initially balked, saying they were swamped with demand from New York and New Jersey. The mayor said sharing the city’s plan for the drive-through testing facility turned the tide. BioReference agreed to process 500 test kits per day.

Duggan later said it took more than his relationship with other executives to close the deal.

“The city of Detroit has a reputation among the corporate and philanthropic community nationally that, if you sign up for something, you’ll be proud of what your partnership with the city produces,” he said.

Detroit’s drive-through testing site opened on March 27 and soon became a model for the nation. As of Wednesday, the city, and its health care partners, had administered 69,567 free coronavirus tests.

Over the next several months, Duggan, whose appreciation for the media’s role in the body politic often seemed like the body’s appreciation for bacteria in the digestive tract, held almost daily news briefings. While he didn’t answer every question, he placed no limits on what reporters could ask.

Duggan announced new initiatives to get personal protective equipment to nursing homes and businesses; financial and legal help for businesses and renters; testing at nursing and group homes, as well as senior citizen housing; new developments and projects; encouraged and praised Detroiters for wearing masks; and threatened businesses that failed to abide by the city’s safety guidelines.

At the April 27 briefing, the normally guarded Duggan opened up a bit.

"I know the pain of losing a family member in the midst of this," he said, referring to his father's death on March 18 after a long illness.

In a rare moment of public reflection, the mayor said what haunted him was the question: "What could we have done sooner?"

A week later, on May 4, he said: "Every single person who dies in Detroit, I look at that detail of that loss."

The briefings are broadcast live on the city's Facebook page and cable channels. In the spring, when White House Coronavirus Task Force Coordinator Dr. Deborah Birx said during a news conference in Washington: “We really want to thank the mayor for making sure everyone is receiving adequate health care and testing,” the city posted that video, too.

At the May 6 briefing, a day after appearing on MSNBC's Rachel Maddow Show, Duggan said: “I must get a half dozen calls every week to do national TV shows. ... They all want to talk about what’s going on in Detroit.”

Deaths from COVID-19, which had been rising to nearly 300 Detroiters a week, fell as testing expanded. The mayor’s message also evolved.

On March 16, he faulted the feds for not providing test kits to states.

After an April 20 Free Press report examined how racial inequity and the coronavirus impacted African-Americans, Duggan began emphasizing the disproportionate impact of COVID-19 on Black Detroiters.

“I guess I hadn’t appreciated that across this country you’ve got the president blaming the states for not having enough testing, you’ve got the states blaming the president for not having enough testing,” the mayor said during his May 6 briefing. “We don’t have time to blame anybody with what’s at stake with the African-American community and the mortality rates; blaming was a waste of time.

“We just said we’re going to get this testing done.”

Roberson, who left the Duggan administration in 2018 to become CEO at the nonprofit Focus: HOPE, said being a white man leading a predominantly Black city has broadened Duggan’s awareness.

She said Duggan bristled at criticism that improvements in Detroit mainly benefitted newcomers and the well-to-do.

“The ‘Two Detroits’ conversation was irritating, but he adjusted to it,” she said. “Same thing with the impact of COVID-19 on Black folks.”

Just when it seemed like Detroit was getting its arms around a once-in-a-century pandemic, a crisis that had been simmering for decades boiled over in Minneapolis — and quickly spread to Detroit.

Detroit will protest

The first march in Detroit to protest the death of George Floyd at the knee of a Minneapolis police officer was mostly peaceful. Hundreds of people marched through Corktown and Southwest Detroit on May 29, under a clear blue sky. Many went home afterward.

But by nightfall, some protesters had mustered a block or so from city hall and squared off with police. Cops in riot gear dodged rocks and other flying objects while throngs of Black Lives Matter protesters choked on tear gas.

There was another night of chaos Saturday. And on Sunday May 31, Duggan announced a temporary curfew to prevent the kind of rioting and looting that was destroying parts of Minneapolis, Seattle and Portland.

The mayor and Police Chief James Craig placed the blame on outsiders — what Duggan called “a small group of people operating here who are intent on initiating destruction and violence.”

Duggan said violent protesters were shifting the focus away from ending police brutality, telling reporters: “They came here to damage property and to throw rocks and bottles at our police.”

Police and marchers squared off Sunday night. Two days later, on June 2, police arrested 127 marchers who defied the 8 p.m. curfew.

There would be other skirmishes over the summer, including a violent confrontation late on Aug. 22 between police and protesters blocking Woodward Avenue that resulted in 44 arrests, but Detroit avoided the destruction and looting that plagued other American cities. Duggan said the credit belonged to Detroiters who stopped outsiders from disrespecting their city.

Dozens of people who lived outside Detroit were arrested over the summer along with Detroiters, but neither Duggan nor police provided any evidence that an Antifa-style leftist group had invaded Detroit and corrupted the protests, which were generally led by local activist Tristan Taylor and his niece Nakia-Renee Wallace. Duggan and Craig met with Taylor and Wallace in early June, but nothing came of the meeting.

Detroit Will Breathe, the group Taylor and Wallace formed, later sued the city in federal court, accusing police and city officials of using brutality to violate protesters' free speech rights. The city accused protesters of assaulting police. A judge issued a temporary restraining order against police before the sides reached an agreement on rules of engagement. The case is pending.

D style

Duggan may be one of the best problem solvers in city hall, but he’s almost certainly the worst fortune-teller.

“I was really thinking that 2020 was going to be the most successful year since I’ve been mayor, and it was all lining up that way,” he told the Free Press in May. “That was how I felt in February … And we’ll get back to it. But we’re going to lose several months.”

Winston Churchill has been credited with saying “Never let a good crisis go to waste.” It’s a maxim that suits Duggan.

“When Detroit started to get hit, there was a lot of, I thought, condescending coverage in the national media, like ‘Poor, broke Detroit won’t be able to survive this,’ ” he said during that May interview. “I think that drove a lot of us to say, ‘This is a different day. We’ve got a management team in place that is as well prepared as any city management team in the country and we’re going to knock this virus down faster than anybody in the country.' ”

He cited Birx’s praise during an April 20 news conference at the White House as affirmation of a new Detroit.

“I think for a lot of us, that was a really important message that Detroit is strong, we’re not the city that was in bankruptcy and couldn’t handle our own problems,” he said. “We’re in a place where literally mayors from all over the country are calling us to say, ‘How did you handle this? … Can we use your playbook?’ ”

Scher, the JP Morgan Chase executive, says he knew Mayor Coleman Young and deals with mayors all over the world.

He called Duggan “one of the top two or three leaders I’ve ever dealt with.”

“He is very focused, he gets into the weeds, he collaborates with people,” Scher said. “If anything, this crisis shows what happens when you have a leader like Mayor Duggan.”

He said the $100 million the bank invested in Detroit shortly after Duggan became mayor has grown to $200 million. Duggan said most of the investment is grants to small businesses and housing projects and loans that would not be available through traditional financing.

“I think this has been a moment where he really has shined,” Roberson said. “If people didn’t think he knew what was going on beforehand, they get it now.”

What many people — including some of his closest colleagues — don’t know about Duggan is what he does for fun.

During one briefing, when the city was warning people not to congregate in parks, Duggan said he spent part of his weekend driving around Belle Isle a half dozen times.

He loves sports, cheering for his alma mater the University of Michigan, plays the card game euchre — always to win — and guzzles Diet Coke. He is said to be funny, with a quick wit, and values family.

Duggan said his worst day on the job was March 17, when bus drivers walked off the job over safety concerns while Duggan’s father Patrick was dying at a hospice in Livonia.

Duggan said he was with his father “who at that point only had hours to live” when the bus drivers struck.

“So I left the hospice, went down to the terminal, listened to the drivers, and was convinced they were right.”

The mayor agreed to implement new safety measures, including suspending fares so passengers would not get too close to drivers, and increasing the bus cleaning schedule. After visiting two terminals, working out an agreement with union officials, and holding a news briefing to announce that drivers would be back on the job the next day, Duggan returned to the hospice to spend what would turn out to be one final evening with his father.

“That was the day where it seemed like everything was happening at once,” he told the Free Press in May.

Asked at that time what he does to relax, he said: “It’s been a long time since I’ve relaxed.”

Duggan declined to discuss any personal or family matters. The mayor's four children are grown. He has two grandchildren.

Critics say what drives Duggan is a lust for power and rewarding friends and favored contractors. They say Detroit's revival has mainly benefitted newcomers, while long-time residents and businesses are pushed out or passed over for things like tax breaks.

“His agenda for inclusion is excluding people who have been here and who have a right to be here,” said Small, the community activist who is also vice chairwoman of the Detroit Charter Revision Commission.

What some may see as cronyism or imperious behavior, others consider loyalty. Trusted Duggan aides have a tendency to follow him from job to job.

In May, Duggan hired Conrad Mallett Jr. as deputy mayor. The pair worked together at the DMC. Mallett, a consummate city hall insider whose father worked for Mayor Jerome Cavanagh in the 1960s, was also chairman of Duggan’s first campaign for mayor. A week later, when it appeared concerns about the spread of the coronavirus in federal prisons might lead to Kilpatrick being released 21 years early, Duggan said at his briefing: “I have a hard time being objective.”

In 2013, Kilpatrick was sentenced to 28 years in federal prison after being convicted of two dozen counts of public corruption. His administration's financial mismanagement helped drive Detroit into bankruptcy. But Duggan worked with Kilpatrick’s father Bernard in the McNamara administration. And Duggan supported Kilpatrick’s 2001 and 2005 campaigns for mayor.

“I have known Kwame since he was in high school and was a big part of supporting everything he did in his career,” Duggan said. “He is an enormously talented person, and I think that talent could do a lot of good in the community.”

Duggan also refused to discipline Wiley, his then chief of staff, after the inspector general urged him to take action after discovering Wiley ordered mayoral appointees to delete emails showing they worked to support Make Your Date. Ha, the inspector general, criticized Duggan's inaction.

"Rules and discipline should apply universally and equally to all employees regardless of the position they hold," Ha wrote in the Free Press on Oct. 25, 2019. Wiley denied issuing a directive.

Some of the harshest criticism of Duggan came from the managing partner of Jones Day, the law firm that oversaw Detroit's bankruptcy. In 2017, Duggan, who had worked closely with Kevyn Orr of Jones Day during his tenure as Detroit's emergency manager, threatened to sue the firm for endangering the city's financial future by underestimating the city's pension obligations.

"Filing this action would place the mayor in a long line of corrupt Detroit politicians who placed personal political ambition above an objective determination of the city's best interest," Stephen Brogan wrote in his letter, obtained by the Free Press through the Freedom of Information Act.

"If this case goes forward, we will prove that it does not — and cannot — serve the interest of your real client, the city of Detroit, but instead is designed only to serve the venal interests of a political hack who has placed personal animus and self-interest ahead of the truth."

Ficano, Duggan's former nemesis, said: "I've not seen any sign of Mike Duggan involved in public corruption or pay-to-play, at least not for himself."

Current and former colleagues say what drives Duggan, besides a good challenge, is making a difference.

“He has an extraordinary determination to make the world a better place,” Mulhern said. “He’s the by-product of his parents. His mom was an incredible social worker, dedicated to at-risk kids … His dad was a conservative, ethical, old Irish Catholic judge. And Mike grew up on that. On changing the world. And he’s just driven to succeed.”

Duggan credits much of whatever success he has had during the pandemic to his team’s experience.

“If the coronavirus had hit my second year, it would have been a lot harder and the burden would have fallen a lot more on me,” he said. “It is far more challenging to do this when your team is just getting started.”

Still, Wiley said Duggan is very involved in everything that’s happening.

“He’s so immersed in details it’s unbelievable,” she said.

What's next

Many months before Duggan announced that he would seek a third term, he already was looking past the pandemic.

One way he planned to promote the city was by pointing to how well the city performed in a crisis.

“Where do you invest in the post-coronavirus world?” he asked. “You look at Detroit and it’s got its act together.”

Rather than expect to be rewarded for creating a testing center that became a model for other cities, or for helping Detroit achieve a lower infection rate than the rest of Michigan, Wiley said Duggan wants to be known as the mayor who put Detroit’s dysfunctional past behind it.

When Duggan took office in 2014, firefighters were complaining they didn’t have toilet paper, even though there was plenty of TP sitting in a city warehouse. The mayor’s team got the toilet paper to the firehouses — and made sure it didn’t happen again.

“How do we come back stronger in a way that emphasizes our competitive edge, our strength as a city?” Wiley said. “I think that’s one thing he wants to be known for.”

No matter how much progress the city has made, Wiley said Duggan still isn’t satisfied.

“‘We’ve got to think about the reboot,’” she quoted him as saying. “‘Once we’re out of the crisis, how do we rebuild?’”

One way the city will rebuild is by tearing down. After Duggan revamped his $250 million bond proposal, the city council voted 5-4 in July to put it on the Nov. 3 ballot. Voters overwhelmingly approved the plan, which also calls for rehabilitating thousands of homes.

Roberson said Duggan rose to the challenge of the pandemic, but will soon have new problems, like potentially higher office vacancy rates and lower income tax revenues as people continue to work from home.

“Detroit’s comeback has always been tenuous,” she said. “And hopeful that no perfect storm happened. And it happened.”

“Can we do it again?” Roberson added. “This will be the challenge of whether Detroit really had a comeback.”

“This ‘after COVID’ will be what Mike is judged on.”

Duggan sounds like he’s comfortable with that — and maybe even encourages it.

“This is the nature of the business, and as the city’s coming back, the expectations are higher and the criticisms grow,” he said. “This is a good thing.”

M.L. Elrick is a Pulitzer Prize- and Emmy Award-winning investigative reporter. Contact him at mlelrick@freepress.com or follow him on Twitter at @elrick, Facebook at ML Elrick and Instagram at ml_elrick. Become a subscriber.
